values.title: Export grant/revokePermission

summary.html:
createResource and related functions do not require tokens but grant does so it feels strange.

It would be nice to be able to use the cloudsim-grant library to do something like this:

csgrant.verifyToken(..., (err, decoded) => {
    csgrant.grantPermission(..., (err, data) => {
      res.jsonp(r)
    })
})

values.description: authenticate function now look for `identities` in token instead of `username`. I kept the `req.user` field as it's quite heavily used in csgrant and other servers. It's set to the first element of the identities array. I can remove it if we decide that it's redundant to have.
values.title: Authenticate identities field

summary.raw: authenticate function now look for `identities` in token instead of `username`. I kept the `req.user` field as it's quite heavily used in csgrant and other servers. It's set to the first element of the identities array. I can remove it if we decide that it's redundant to have.
summary.html: authenticate function now look for identities in token instead of username. I kept the req.user field as it's quite heavily used in csgrant and other servers. It's set to the first element of the identities array. I can remove it if we decide that it's redundant to have.

values.description:
new features:

* setPermissionsRoutes (will make it easier to fix grant and revoke)
* save/load data (for not resources things)

refactor: the index.js cannot be required from other submodules (circular dependencies) so I started to split it up. Index was copied to grant.js, and routes.js was created. Functionality is unchanged.

values.description:
This adds mandatory expiration to all tokens. Let's start with a date far in the future (weeks), and narrow it down in the future (like a few hours session).

Expect a very simple cloudsim-auth PR to enable this feature.

Happy hacking!
values.title: Expire tokens

values.description:
Added 3 functions (`setResourceLocal`, `grantPermissionLocal`, `revokePermissionLocal`) for reconstructing resources from raw db data without rewriting back to the database.

Also added timing logs to help us debug on live site

There are minor perf tweaks to code
values.title: Prevent clearing and rewriting to database on reload

summary.raw:
Added 3 functions (`setResourceLocal`, `grantPermissionLocal`, `revokePermissionLocal`) for reconstructing resources from raw db data without rewriting back to the database.

Also added timing logs to help us debug on live site

There are minor perf tweaks to code
summary.html:
Added 3 functions (setResourceLocal, grantPermissionLocal, revokePermissionLocal) for reconstructing resources from raw db data without rewriting back to the database.

Also added timing logs to help us debug on live site

There are minor perf tweaks to code

values.description:
This PR build on top of pull request #31. Please review that one first.

The state of resources is now saved in the database

After updating a server to use these changes, the expected behavior is:

1. the first time a server is launched and if there exist no states in db, the resources will be reconstructed from the logs (old way). The resources will then be written to db as a key (`[name]:state`) - this is the database state.

1. subsequent operations, e.g. create resource, grant, revoke, will be written as logs to the db (same as before). A counter (`[name]:state-backlog`) is used to keep track of the number of operations performed after a saved state

1. once 10000 number of db operations have been written, a new state will be saved which overwrites the old one. The `state-backlog` counter resets to 0.

1. when the server is redeployed, it loads the latest saved state from db to create the resources. It then uses the counter to determine how many operations are needed to reconstruct the resources back to the most recent state before the redeployment.
values.title: Support saving and reloading database states

summary.raw:
This PR build on top of pull request #31. Please review that one first.

The state of resources is now saved in the database

After updating a server to use these changes, the expected behavior is:

1. the first time a server is launched and if there exist no states in db, the resources will be reconstructed from the logs (old way). The resources will then be written to db as a key (`[name]:state`) - this is the database state.

1. subsequent operations, e.g. create resource, grant, revoke, will be written as logs to the db (same as before). A counter (`[name]:state-backlog`) is used to keep track of the number of operations performed after a saved state

1. once 10000 number of db operations have been written, a new state will be saved which overwrites the old one. The `state-backlog` counter resets to 0.

1. when the server is redeployed, it loads the latest saved state from db to create the resources. It then uses the counter to determine how many operations are needed to reconstruct the resources back to the most recent state before the redeployment.
summary.html:
This PR build on top of pull request #31. Please review that one first.

The state of resources is now saved in the database

After updating a server to use these changes, the expected behavior is:

  1. the first time a server is launched and if there exist no states in db, the resources will be reconstructed from the logs (old way). The resources will then be written to db as a key ([name]:state) - this is the database state.

  2. subsequent operations, e.g. create resource, grant, revoke, will be written as logs to the db (same as before). A counter ([name]:state-backlog) is used to keep track of the number of operations performed after a saved state

  3. once 10000 number of db operations have been written, a new state will be saved which overwrites the old one. The state-backlog counter resets to 0.

  4. when the server is redeployed, it loads the latest saved state from db to create the resources. It then uses the counter to determine how many operations are needed to reconstruct the resources back to the most recent state before the redeployment.

values.description:
This makes sure that new root resources are added to the database on redeployment.

Note: The assumption here is that the root resources will always be available and are not to be deleted from the database. If you delete the root resource and redeploy, they will be added back.

The other solution I could think of is to provide a route that allows the admin to create new resources.
values.title: Always add initial root resources

summary.raw:
This makes sure that new root resources are added to the database on redeployment.

Note: The assumption here is that the root resources will always be available and are not to be deleted from the database. If you delete the root resource and redeploy, they will be added back.

The other solution I could think of is to provide a route that allows the admin to create new resources.
summary.html:
This makes sure that new root resources are added to the database on redeployment.

Note: The assumption here is that the root resources will always be available and are not to be deleted from the database. If you delete the root resource and redeploy, they will be added back.

The other solution I could think of is to provide a route that allows the admin to create new resources.

values.description:
the `type` passed in `req` was never used and was always set to `application/zip`.

Fixed to use the specified download type in req
